Fig. 1 Enlarged HR-TEM images of Mo oxide catalysts that are (a) not reduced, (b) reduced at 600 °C under N2/H2 flow, and (c) reduced at 800 °C under NH3 flow. (d) HR-TEM images and (e) the corresponding EDX spectroscopy maps of MoO3-NH3-800. Fig 1 Fig. 2 (a) XRD patterns ( : MoO3, : MoO2, : Mo, : Mo2N) of Mo oxide catalysts that are non-reduced, reduced in situ at various temperatures (400–700 °C) under N2/H2 flow, and reduced ex situ at 800 °C under NH3 flow. (b) Schematic of changes in the crystal structure of Mo oxide catalysts during reduction. Fig 2 Fig. 3 XPS Mo 3d spectra of Mo oxide catalysts that are not reduced, reduced at various temperatures (400–700 °C) under N2/H2 flow, and reduced at 800 °C under NH3 flow. Fig 3 Fig. 4 (a) Mass-averaged NH3 formation rates (1.0 MPa, 400 °C, 1 h) on Mo oxide catalysts that are not reduced, reduced at various temperatures (400–700 °C) under N2/H2 flow, and reduced at 800 °C under NH3 flow. Mass-averaged NH3 formation rates over MoO3-N2/H2-600 and MoO3-NH3-800 as functions of (b) N2 pressure (34–507 kPa N2, 507 kPa H2, 400 °C), (c) H2 pressure (170 kPa N2, 85–845 kPa H2, 400 °C), and (d) reaction temperature (253 kPa N2, 760 kPa H2, 325–450 °C). Trend lines indicate power-law fits for (b) and (c) and linear fits for (d). Fig 4 Fig. 5 TPSR profiles for (a) the first Ar/D2-reaction test of the fresh MoO3-NH3-800 and (b) the second Ar/D2-reaction test after N2 treatment of the used catalyst. The N2 treatment was performed after the first Ar/D2-TPSR for 1 h at 400 °C and 0.1 MPa. Fig 5 Fig. 6 Energy diagrams for associative NH3 synthesis over (a) MoO2 surface with Ov and (b) Mo2N surface with Nv and dissociative NH3 synthesis over (c) MoO2 surface with Ov and (d) Mo2N surface with Nv as a function of reaction temperature. Fig 6 Fig. 7 (a) Surface structures for MoO2 with Ov (left) and Mo2N with Nv (right). The synthesis of NH3 from N2 and H2 is a significant chemical process, because essential products such as fertilizers and industrial chemicals can be obtained from NH3. In the catalytic synthesis of NH3, N2 activation is generally considered a kinetically relevant step (KRS). Therefore, advanced heterogeneous catalysts that promote N2 conversion have been extensively investigated. In this study, the roles of O and N vacancies (Ov and Nv) of Mo oxide formed during reduction were kinetically evaluated and compared using structural characterization, isotope experiments, kinetic studies, and density functional theory calculations. On the Mo oxide catalyst with Ov, NH3 was formed by a dissociative mechanism, and the surface reaction involving the adsorbed N* and H* was considered the KRS. However, on the catalyst with Nv, NH3 was formed by an associative mechanism, and N–N dissociation of N2H2* species by H* to produce NH3 was considered the KRS. The catalyst with Ov resulted in an NH3 synthesis rate of 5.6 mmol gMo −1 h−1 under relatively mild conditions (1.0 MPa and 400 °C), thus outperforming the catalyst with Nv (0.3 mmol gMo −1 h−1). These results provide insight into the importance of anionic vacancies in reducible metal oxides for NH3 synthesis. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Ammonia synthesis Kinetics N2 activation Oxygen vacancy Nitrogen vacancy Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Ammonia is an important raw material that is used to produce several essential industrial chemicals [1]. It is predominantly synthesized via the Haber–Bosch process, which involves Fe-based catalysts. Ammonia synthesis is a reversible exothermic reaction (∆H 0 = −92 kJ mol−1), and a low temperature thermodynamically favors the reaction; however, high operating temperatures (400–600 °C) and pressures (15–25 MPa) are kinetically required for a high NH3 yield [2-4]. To reduce the energy consumption, NH3 production under mild conditions has been comprehensively investigated. Moreover, NH3 synthesis has attracted attention as a storage method for renewable energy [5] and potential carbon-free fuel [6]. Various thermal [7-9], electrochemical [10,11], plasmonic [12,13], and photocatalytic [14-16] methods have been employed for NH3 synthesis. N2 activation (adsorption or dissociation) is considered a kinetically relevant step (KRS) in NH3 synthesis [17-21], and metal nitrides [22-24] and reducible oxides [25-27] have attracted attention as supports or active materials for this reaction. The Hosono group reported metal nitride complexes (e.g., Ni/LaN [28], Ni/La–Al–N [29], and Co/La–Al–N [29]), which are dual-active catalysts wherein N vacancies (Nv) activate N2, and the metals dissociate H2. They emphasized that Nv sites are suitable for N2 activation, resulting in high reactivity of metal nitride catalysts (e.g., 5.5 mmolNH3 gcat −1 h−1 on Ni/LaN nanoparticles, 400 °C, 0.1 MPa, 36 000 mL gcat −1 h−1) for NH3 synthesis. Zeinalipour-Yazdi et al. also suggested that gaseous N2 is minimally adsorbed on defect-free surfaces but is efficiently activated on Nv; Nv are readily formed on the nitride surface under the reaction conditions considered, and NH3 is easily formed on Nv (Eley–Rideal/Mars–van Krevelen mechanism) [30]. Humphreys et al. investigated the effect of anion vacancies of a Ce1−zSmzO2−xNy support on the reactivity of Fe-based catalysts. They reported that anion vacancies, particularly Nv, are excellent promoters of NH3 synthesis, because N2 and H2 gases are adsorbed and dissociated into N3− and H− ions at these sites [31]. Lin et al. prepared a Ru/CeO2 catalyst by changing the morphology of CeO2 and observed that the catalyst contained high concentrations of O vacancies (Ov), which enhanced the adsorption of H2 and N2 [32]. This catalyst resulted in high NH3 synthesis rates (250 mmolNH3 gcat −1 h−1, 430 °C, 10 MPa, 60 000 mL gcat −1 h−1). Huang et al. reported that Ov formed on a Ba5Ta4O15 support (under the reaction conditions of 400 °C, 0.1 MPa, and 36 000 mL gcat −1 h−1) activated N2 and formed NH3 without active metals (e.g., Ru) [33]. Ru and Cs (promoter) facilitated the formation of Ov on the Ba5Ta4O15 support, thereby increasing the NH3 synthesis rate (5.88 mmolNH3 gcat −1 h−1). Collectively, the anion vacancies (Ov and Nv) in reducible metal oxides are expected to play important roles (i.e., promote N2 cleavage) in NH3 synthesis. In this study, we selected Mo oxides as model reducible oxide catalysts to confirm their reactivities and reaction mechanisms for NH3 synthesis on Ov and Nv. These oxides were treated under various reduction conditions to introduce Ov and Nv onto the catalyst surface. The reduced materials were characterized (vide infra) and denoted according to the reduction gas (X) and temperature (Y; °C) (MoO3-X-Y). The mass-averaged NH3 synthesis rates on the Mo oxide catalysts with the anion vacancies were compared to examine the differences between the corresponding NH3 synthesis mechanisms. Kinetic studies and density functional theory (DFT) calculations were employed to determine the effect of the type of anion vacancies in the reducible oxide on the NH3 synthesis mechanism. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Structural analysis of the reduced Mo oxide catalysts The high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) images of the non-reduced and reduced Mo oxide catalysts reveal that all samples have arbitrary shapes and sizes (Fig. S1). Based on the enlarged HR-TEM image (Fig. 1 a–c), the interplanar distance of non-reduced MoO3 matches well (0.187 nm) with the (002) plane of MoO3 [34]. Upon reducing the sample at 600 °C under N2/H2 flow, the interplanar distance is increased to 0.242 nm, corresponding to the (020) plane of monoclinic MoO2 [35]. The interplanar distance of MoO3-NH3-800 is 0.238 nm, which matches well with the (112) plane of Mo2N [36]. These results suggest that the crystalline structure of Mo oxide is modified depending on the reduction conditions. MoO3-NH3-800 displays an average particle size of 39 nm (Fig. 1d) with interparticle pores around the Mo2N particles. This is likely due to the release of H2O gas with shrinkage of the oxide particles during reduction. According to the energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) mapping (Fig. 1e), these particles comprise Mo and N, indicating the conversion of the oxide particle to nitrides after reduction at 800 °C under NH3 flow. The O species with lower distribution densities is likely adsorbed on the particle surface during passivation. Similarly, Mo, N, and O species are highly distributed on the MoO3-N2/H2-600 catalyst (Fig. S2). The density of the O species in the MoO3-N2/H2-600 catalyst is higher than that in the MoO3-NH3-800 catalyst. This observation suggests that the structure of the MoO3-NH3-800 catalyst is similar to that of molybdenum nitride, whereas the structure of the MoO3-N2/H2-600 catalyst is similar to that of molybdenum oxide. The crystallographic changes in the samples are confirmed based on the results of the X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis (Figs. 2 and S3). The peaks of non-reduced Mo oxide are all indexed to orthorhombic α-MoO3 ( , PDF#76-1003). After Mo oxide is reduced by N2/H2 at 400 °C, the XRD patterns are assigned to orthorhombic α-MoO3 (PDF#76-1003) and MoO2 ( , PDF#78-1069). Upon increasing the reduction temperature to 500 °C, the peaks attributed to MoO2 are predominant. The catalyst reduced at 600 °C consists of MoO2 ( , PDF#78-1069) and Mo metal ( , PDF#89-5023), and that reduced at 700 °C contains Mo2N ( , PDF#25-1366). Thus, the results indicate that the oxide is gradually reduced with increasing temperature; the oxide is substantially reduced and the nitride phase is gradually formed when the reduction temperature exceeds 700 °C (Fig. 2b). This transformation is non-topotactic [37] and occurs during both N2/H2 and NH3 treatments, except that the temperature at which the structural change occurs is lower under NH3 flow than under N2/H2 flow (Fig. S3). The structural characteristics of the MoO3-N2/H2-800 catalyst are identical to those of the MoO3-N2/H2-700 catalyst (Fig. S3(b)); consequently, 700 °C is selected as the highest reduction temperature for N2 and H2 treatment. The XRD pattern of MoO3-NH3-800 shows that this catalyst contains only the Mo2N ( , PDF#25-1366) phase. The peaks corresponding to the Mo2N phase in MoO3-NH3-800 shift to a lower degree compared with those in MoO3-N2/H2-700, indicating that the amount of N in the Mo nitride structure is higher in the MoO3-NH3-800 catalyst [38]. A similar trend is confirmed by the Mo 3d X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) results (Fig. 3 and Table 1 ). Four Mo species are detected in the samples: Mo6+, Mo5+, ‘O-rich’ Mo4+, and ‘N-rich’ Mo4+ at 232.7, 231.6, 230.3, and 229.2 eV, respectively [39]. Mo4+ and Mo5+ are formed during reduction, whereas the Mo6+ species exists before reduction. The concentration of the low-valence Mo species in the MoO3-N2/H2 samples increases with increasing reduction temperature. In particular, the MoO3-N2/H2-600 catalyst has the largest number of undercoordinated Mo4+ sites bound to O (purple area in Fig. 3, 34 %). When the reduction temperature is increased to 700 °C, the number of Mo4+ sites bound to N is greater than that of Mo4+ sites bound to O. This finding suggests that Ov are formed during reduction, and the concentration of Ov increases with increasing reduction temperature; these vacancies are gradually occupied by N for the MoO3-N2/H2 samples. The Mo4+ sites that are bound to N are primarily formed (green area in Fig. 3, 59 %) in the MoO3-NH3-800 catalyst; consequently, this catalyst is expected to have numerous Nv on the surface under NH3 synthesis conditions. The XRD and XPS results collectively suggest that MoO3-N2/H2-600 has abundant Ov, whereas MoO3-NH3-800 has abundant Nv under the given reaction conditions. 2.2 Rate and mechanism of NH3 synthesis over the Mo oxide catalysts NH3 synthesis was performed in a fixed bed reactor with N2 and H2 gases (N2:H2 = 1:3) at 1.0 MPa and catalysts (50 mg) pretreated under different conditions (Figs. 4 a and S4). For the non-reduced Mo oxide catalyst, the produced NH3 was not detectable at 1.5 h, indicating that α-MoO3 has no reactivity for NH3 synthesis. A small amount of NH3 is produced after 1.5 h of reaction on the MoO3 catalyst (Fig. S5), which may be attributed to the surface reconstruction of the catalyst under the given reaction conditions. Notably, the catalytic activity of the Mo oxide catalysts varies with the N2/H2 reduction temperature; a high NH3 synthesis rate is obtained at an optimal temperature. The highest NH3 synthesis rate (5.6 mmolNH3 gMo −1 h−1) is achieved when the catalyst is reduced at 600 °C under N2/H2 flow, and this catalyst is expected to have the largest amount of Ov based on the structural analysis results. The reactivity of the MoO3-N2/H2-600 catalyst decreased by 13 % during the initial hour of the reaction; subsequently, the NH3 synthesis rate was maintained for 94 h (Fig. S6). However, the NH3 synthesis rate with MoO3-NH3-800 is approximately eight times lower than that with MoO3-N2/H2-600, suggesting that the Ov formed on the reduced Mo oxide surface are considerably more active than the Nv. The specific activities calculated based on the surface areas of the prepared catalysts are also compared (Table S1). When the reduction temperature is increased to 500 °C, the surface area decreases (from 1.56 to 1.42 m2 g-1), but the change is not substantial. The surface area gradually increases when the reduction temperature is increased, and the MoO3-NH3-800 catalyst shows the highest surface area (10.5 m2 g-1) owing to the interparticle pores formed during reduction (Fig. 1 (d)). However, the specific activity of the MoO3-NH3-800 catalyst is 50 times lower than that of the MoO3-N2/H2-600 catalyst, indicating that the Nv formed during NH3 treatment do not improve the NH3 synthesis reactivity. To investigate the behavior of NH3 synthesis over Mo2N, we conducted Ar/D2-temperature-programmed surface reaction (TPSR) measurements using MoO3-NH3-800 catalyst (Fig. 5 ). During the TPSR experiments, NHx fragments were detected in the m/z range of 16–20, corresponding to m/z = 16 (NH2), 17 (NDH and NH3), 18 (NDH2 and ND2), 19 (ND2H), and 20 (ND3), respectively. This suggests that the H– species incorporated on the catalyst surface by nitridation were involved in the synthesis of NH3. The TPSR peaks for NHx fragments were classified into three groups based on the desorption temperature: αNHx, βNHx, and γNHx. Fragments with higher peak temperatures are likely more strongly bound to Mo atoms and thus more difficult to hydrogenate. For the fragments containing H– species (m/z = 17, 18, and 19), the intensity of the γNHx peak is higher than those of the other peaks (Fig. 5a). Notably, the NH2 (m/z = 16) is found only at the γNHx peak position, indicating that most NHx fragments remaining from the nitridation process are strongly bound to Mo species. Moreover, ND3 (m/z = 20) is barely detected due to the presence of the incorporated H– species. We performed a subsequent Ar/D2-TPSR measurement after regenerating the lattice nitrogen consumed during the first TPSR via N2 treatment (Fig. 5b). For all NHx fragments, the βNHx peaks are increased, while the γNHx peaks are decreased. Moreover, no NH2 fragment (m/z = 16) was detected, indicating that the H– species were significantly reduced during the first Ar/D2-TPSR measurement. In the absence of the H– species, the increase in ND3 (m/z = 20) production demonstrates that the lattice nitrogen in Mo2N can participate in the NH3 synthesis reaction, potentially leading to a significant number of Nv on the Mo2N surface. The NH3 synthesis mechanism over heterogeneous catalysts is widely acknowledged; in particular, dissociative and associative mechanisms are possible over catalysts with anion vacancies [4,40-44]. In this study, both mechanisms were examined using kinetic studies and DFT calculations. The dissociative mechanism follows the Langmuir–Hinshelwood model. H2 is dissociatively adsorbed on the catalyst surface; accordingly, the mechanism is divided into seven elementary steps (Eqs. (1)–(7)): (1) N 2 ( g ) + * ⇄ N 2 * (2) H 2 ( g ) + 2 # ⇄ 2 H # (3) N 2 * + * ⇄ 2 N * (4) N * + H # ⇄ N H * + # (5) N H * + H # ⇄ N H 2 * + # (6) N H 2 * + H # ⇄ N H 3 * + # (7) N H 3 * ⇄ N H 3 ( g ) + * , where (g) denotes gaseous species and * and # denote adsorbed species. The associative mechanism is divided into nine elementary steps (Eqs. (8)–(16)): (8) N 2 ( g ) + * ⇄ N 2 * (9) H 2 ( g ) + 2 # ⇄ 2 H # (10) N 2 * + H # ⇄ N 2 H * + # (11) N 2 H * + H # ⇄ N 2 H 2 * + # (12) N 2 H 2 * + H # ⇄ N * + N H 3 ( g ) + # (13) N * + H # ⇄ N H * + # (14) N H * + H # ⇄ N H 2 * + # (15) N H 2 * + H # ⇄ N H 3 * + # (16) N H 3 * ⇄ N H 3 ( g ) + * , where (g) denotes gaseous species and * and # denote adsorbed species. The NH3 formation rate as a function of the partial pressure of the reactant corroborates the abovementioned elementary steps. Fig. 4b and 4c show the mass-averaged NH3 synthesis rates over MoO3-N2/H2-600 and MoO3-NH3-800 as functions of the N2 and H2 pressures, respectively. The NH3 synthesis rate increases linearly with the N2 pressure ( r N H 3 ∝ P N 2 0.9 ± 0.04 ; 34–507 kPa N2, 507 kPa H2, and 400 °C) on MoO3-NH3-800, whereas the rate increases sub-linearly with the N2 pressure ( r N H 3 ∝ P N 2 0.6 ± 0.03 ; 34–507 kPa N2, 507 kPa H2, and 400 °C) on MoO3-N2/H2-600. Consequently, NH3 synthesis is considered to proceed via different transition states or different rate-determining steps over the two catalysts. The NH3 synthesis rates increase linearly with H2 pressure ( r N H 3 ∝ P H 2 0.9 ± 0.09 ; 170 kPa N2, 85–845 kPa H2, and 400 °C) over both catalysts. The measured turnover rates on MoO3-N2/H2-600 for NH3 synthesis are consistent with the dissociative mechanism presented in Eqs. (1)–(7). Here, we assume that any step among Eqs (4)–(6) can be a KRS. If the forward reaction of step (4) is a KRS, the law of mass action predicts that the NH3 synthesis rates depend linearly on both the number of N* and H#. Accordingly, the NH3 synthesis rate (r) can be expressed as follows: (17) r = k 4 [ N * ] [ H # ] , where k 4 represents the rate constant for the surface hydrogenation of N * species (step (4)). We assume that the other steps (except step (4)) rapidly reach equilibrium, making r an explicit function of P N 2 and P H 2 . Subsequently, a site balance constraint requires the sum of the number of all possible adsorbed species to be equal to the total number of active sites ([ L * + L # ]). This provides a detailed rate expression for NH3 synthesis over MoO3-N2/H2-600 catalysts. (18) r [ L * ] + [ L # ] = k 4 K 2 K 3 1 2 K 4 P N 2 1 2 P H 2 ( 1 + K 1 P N 2 + K 1 1 2 K 3 1 2 P N 2 1 2 + P N H 3 K 2 K 5 K 6 K 7 P H 2 + P N H 3 K 2 1 2 K 6 K 7 P H 2 1 2 + P N H 3 K 7 ) ( 1 + K 2 1 2 P H 2 1 2 ) , where k i and K i are the rate constant and equilibrium constant for step i, respectively. This derivation accounts for non-competitive adsorption between atomic H and the N2-derived intermediates by assuming the involvement of two distinct types of sites. The first type (#) binds only H atoms, whereas the second type (*) binds all N2-derived intermediates (e.g., N2*, N*, and NH2*). This complete rate equation (Eq. (18)) can be simplified up to the point when the active sites become saturated with the intermediates. The most abundant reactive intermediate (MARI) is determined based on the DFT calculation; the most energetically stable species over the reaction coordinates is regarded as the MARI. For the MoO3-N2/H2-600 catalyst, NH2* is the MARI based on the calculation results (Fig. 6 a and 6c), and the simplified rate equation can be obtained as follows: (19) r [ L * ] + [ L # ] = k 4 K 2 K 3 1 2 K 4 K 6 K 7 P N 2 1 2 P H 2 P N H 3 . Based on Eq. (19), the rate varies sub-linearly with P N 2 and increases linearly with P H 2 , corresponding to the rate measurements presented in Fig. 4b and 4c, respectively. If the forward reactions of steps (5) and (6) are KRS, detailed rate expressions can be derived as follows: (20) r [ L * ] + [ L # ] = k 5 K 1 1 2 K 2 1 2 K 3 1 2 P N 2 1 2 P H 2 1 2 ( 1 + K 1 P N 2 + K 1 1 2 K 3 1 2 P N 2 1 2 + K 1 1 2 K 2 1 2 K 3 1 2 K 4 P N 2 1 2 P H 2 1 2 + P N H 3 K 2 1 2 K 6 K 7 P H 2 1 2 + P N H 3 K 7 ) ( 1 + K 2 1 2 P H 2 1 2 ) (21) r [ L * ] + [ L # ] = k 6 K 1 1 2 K 2 3 2 K 3 1 2 K 4 K 5 P N 2 1 2 P H 2 3 2 ( 1 + K 1 P N 2 + K 1 1 2 K 3 1 2 P N 2 1 2 + K 1 1 2 K 2 1 2 K 3 1 2 K 4 P N 2 1 2 P H 2 1 2 + K 1 1 2 K 2 K 3 1 2 K 4 K 5 P N 2 1 2 P H 2 + P N H 3 K 7 ) ( 1 + K 2 1 2 P H 2 1 2 ) , The active sites (*) are saturated by NH2*; correspondingly, Eqs. (22) and (23) do not agree with the rate measurements in Fig. 4b and 4c. Therefore, these results suggest that NH3 synthesis on the MoO3-N2/H2-600 catalyst follows the dissociative mechanism, and the surface reaction between N* and H* is the KRS, with NH2* as the MARI. The measured turnover rates on MoO3-NH3-800 for NH3 synthesis linearly depend on P N 2 , which is indicative of the associative mechanism presented in Eqs. (8)–(16). The rate equations are expressed by assuming that any step among steps (8, 10–15) is a KRS for the overall NH3 synthesis, and the other steps (except the KRS) rapidly reach equilibrium. ] = k 15 K 8 K 9 3 K 10 K 11 K 12 K 13 K 14 P N 2 P H 2 3 P N H 3 − 1 ( 1 + K 8 P N 2 + K 8 K 9 1 2 K 10 P H 2 1 2 P N 2 + K 8 K 9 K 10 K 11 P H 2 P N 2 + K 8 K 9 3 2 K 10 K 11 K 12 P H 2 3 2 P N 2 P N H 3 + K 8 K 9 2 K 10 K 11 K 12 K 13 P H 2 2 P N 2 P N H 3 + K 8 K 9 5 2 K 10 K 11 K 12 K 13 K 14 P H 2 5 2 P N 2 P N H 3 + P N H 3 K 16 ) ( 1 + K 9 1 2 P H 2 1 2 ) , where k i and K i are the rate constant and the equilibrium constant for step i, respectively, and non-competitive adsorption is assumed. NH3* is considered the MARI, because the DFT calculations show that the Gibbs free energy of the NH3* species on the MoO3-NH3-800 surface is the lowest (Fig. 6b and 6d), and the H* species is also assumed to occupy the active sites (#). These assumptions result in the following simplified equations: (31) r [ L * ] + [ L # ] = k 8 K 9 1 2 K 15 K 16 P H 2 1 2 P N 2 P N H 3 (32) r [ L * ] + [ L # ] = k 10 K 8 K 16 P N 2 P N H 3 (33) r [ L * ] + [ L # ] = k 11 K 8 K 9 1 2 K 10 K 16 P N 2 P H 2 1 2 P N H 3 (34) r [ L * ] + [ L # ] = k 12 K 8 K 9 K 10 K 11 K 16 P N 2 P H 2 P N H 3 (35) r [ L * ] + [ L # ] = k 13 K 8 K 9 3 2 K 10 K 11 K 12 K 16 P N 2 P H 2 3 2 P N H 3 2 (36) r [ L * ] + [ L # ] = k 14 K 8 K 9 2 K 10 K 11 K 12 K 13 K 16 P N 2 P H 2 2 P N H 3 2 (37) r [ L * ] + [ L # ] = k 15 K 8 K 9 5 2 K 10 K 11 K 12 K 13 K 14 K 16 P N 2 P H 2 5 2 P N H 3 2 . Among these simplified forms, Eq. (34) is quantitatively consistent with the turnover rates that increase with both P N 2 and P H 2 (Fig. 4b and 4c, respectively). Thus, the results indicate that NH3 synthesis on the MoO3-NH3-800 catalyst follows the associative mechanism; the hydrogenation of N2H2* to form NH3 is the KRS, and NH3* is the MARI. The kinetic results imply that the reaction mechanism is completely different based on the type of anion vacancy in reduced Mo oxides. The apparent activation energies (Ea,app ) were determined from the NH3 synthesis rates plotted as functions of the inverse temperature for MoO3-N2/H2-600 and MoO3-NH3-800 (Fig. 4d; 253 kPa N2, 760 kPa H2, and 325–450 °C). The Ea,app of MoO3-N2/H2-600 is 62.9 ± 2.4 kJ mol−1, whereas that of MoO3-NH3-800 is 77.5 ± 4.7 kJ mol−1. This difference possibly indicates that MoO3-N2/H2-600 easily activates N2 and outperforms MoO3-NH3-800 in NH3 synthesis. The DFT calculation results also confirm the changes in the NH3 synthesis mechanism of the MoO3-N2/H2-600 and MoO3-NH3-800 catalysts. We used MoO2(011) with Ov [45] and Mo2N(001) with Nv [46] as model surfaces for the MoO3-N2/H2-600 and MoO3-NH3-800 catalysts, respectively (Fig. 7 a) and compared the corresponding reaction mechanisms. Fig. 8 shows the energetics of the favored mechanism for each surface. On the MoO2 surface, N2 dissociation (ΔGrxn 400 °C = −1.06 eV) is energetically favored over N2 hydrogenation (ΔGrxn 400 °C = 0.98 eV; Fig. 6a and 6c); therefore, the dissociative mechanism is more probable. However, the Mo2N surface favors the associative mechanism because the two strongly adsorbed N* species require a higher reaction energy to form two NH3 molecules (Fig. 6b and 6d). The adsorption of N2 on the MoO2 surface is exoergic, whereas that on the Mo2N surface is endoergic, resulting in a larger initial barrier for the Mo2N surface. Furthermore, the hydrogenation of the N species is energetically more favorable on the MoO2 surface than on the Mo2N surface, as evidenced by the more negative reaction energies. These results suggest that N2 adsorption and surface reactions between the N and H intermediates are more facile at the Ov sites of MoO2 than at the Nv sites of Mo2N. 3 Conclusion The surface or crystalline structure of Mo oxide was altered by the reduction conditions, thereby affecting the catalytic reactivity for NH3 synthesis. The catalyst reduced at 600 °C under N2/H2 flow exhibited the highest NH3 synthesis rate (5.6 mmolNH3 gMo −1 h−1, 1 MPa, 400 °C) among the catalysts reduced at various temperatures, and this rate was eight times higher than that on MoO3-NH3-800 at identical kinetic regimes. Comprehensive analysis, kinetic analysis, and DFT calculation results revealed that the abundant Ov sites in the MoO3-N2/H2-600 catalyst enhanced N2 activation during dissociative NH3 synthesis. In contrast, MoO3-NH3-800 catalyst contained Nv on its surface, but gaseous N2 adsorption and N–N dissociation of N2H2* species scarcely occurred on this catalyst, resulting in low reactivity for NH3 synthesis. These results provide insights into the design and development of high-performance heterogeneous catalysts for NH3 synthesis, emphasizing the importance of anion vacancies in reducible metal oxides. 4 Experimental 4.1 Catalyst synthesis Various reduced Mo oxides were used in this study. Mo oxides (MoO3) were purchased (SAMCHUN CHEMICAL, 99.0 %) and calcined in flowing air at 450 °C for 2 h to remove organic residues before use. MoO3-N2/H2 samples were prepared by introducing pre-sintered MoO3 (1.0–1.2 g) into a tubular furnace (Thermo Fisher scientific, TF55035C–1) and flowing a mixture of 15 mL N2 and 45 mL H2 gases. The sample was heated at a rate of 5 °C min–1 from room temperature to the designated reduction temperature (400–700 °C), and the temperature was held for 2 h. After cooling to room temperature, the sample was passivated with a 1 % O2/N2 gas. MoO3-NH3 was prepared similarly using the tubular furnace. After introducing pre-sintered MoO3 (1.0–1.2 g) into the tubular furnace, the sample was heated at a rate of 10 °C min–1 from room temperature to 800 °C in 30 mL min–1 NH3 gas flow, and held at 800 °C for 2 h. After cooling to room temperature, the sample was passivated with a 1 % O2/N2 gas. The reduced materials were characterized and denoted according to the reduction gas (X) and temperature (Y;°C) (MoO3-X-Y). 4.2 Catalyst characterization The samples were analyzed using an X-ray diffractometer (Rigaku MiniFlex II). This instrument uses Cu Kα radiation, and the analysis was performed at 30 kV and 15 mA. The crystal structure of the sample was analyzed at a scanning speed of 10.0° min–1, scanning width of 0.02°, and scanning range of 10–50°. For the in situ analysis, the catalysts were pretreated by heating to the designated temperature at 5 °C min–1 in flowing 75 % H2/N2 (101 kPa, 60 cm3 min–1) and holding for 2 h before the XRD measurements. The morphologies of the reduced MoO3 samples were confirmed by HR-TEM and EDX images using a Talos F200 microscope. The average particle sizes were determined by measuring approximately 300 particles in the TEM images of each sample. The X-ray photoelectron spectra were acquired under an ultrahigh vacuum using a Kratos AXIS NOVA X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (Al Kα, 15 kV, 10 mA, Shimadzu). All binding energies were calibrated with the adventitious C (C 1s) signal at 284.5 eV. The spectra were processed using XPSPEAK41 software by subtracting the Shirley background and fitting a mixed Lorentzian–Gaussian function with initial guesses for peak positions from the literature [39]. This characterization was performed ex situ, and we attempted to protect our samples from the air and moisture as much as possible. Adsorption and desorption isotherms of N2 were obtained using a Micrometrics TriStar 3000 analyzer. The catalysts were loaded into a glass vessel and heated to 120 °C for 12 h under vacuum to desorb water. The degassed samples were weighed, and then the isotherms were obtained. The surface areas of the catalysts were determined using the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller method. TPSR experiments were conducted using an AutoChem II instrument (Micromeritics) with Ar/D2 gases. MoO3-NH3 (20 mg) was charged into a quartz cell, and it was activated at 700 °C for 1 h with a N2/H2 to reduce the surface oxygen by passivation. A gas stream containing D2 and Ar (Ar/D2 = 10:1) was applied within the temperature range of 50–400 °C with a ramping rate of 5 °C min–1. The reaction products were monitored with a quadrupole mass spectrometer (OmniStar GSD 350, Pfeiffer Vacuum). 4.3 Catalytic reaction rate measurements The NH3 synthesis rates were measured using a fixed-bed Inconel reactor with 50 mg of a pelletized catalyst at differential conversion (<0.3 %). The conditions used in this study avoided mass transfer constraints. The catalyst temperature was measured by a thermocouple closely located on the catalyst bed. SiC was used with the desired amount of a catalyst to maintain the identical volume of the catalyst bed. The gas flow rates (N2 and H2) were controlled using mass flow controllers (BROOKS instrument) and the system was pressurized using a back-pressure regulator (TESCOM). The catalysts were pretreated in situ by heating to 600 °C at 5 °C min−1 in a flow of 75 % H2/N2 gas (101 kPa, 60 cm3 min−1) and holding for 1 h followed by cooling to target reaction temperature (400 °C), and reaction measurement was conducted at a pressure of 1.0 MPa. The produced NH3 was trapped in an aqueous H2SO4 solution (30 mM), whereas the proton conductivity of the sampling solution was recorded using a conductivity meter (Orion Star A212, Thermo Fisher Scientific) every minute. The rate of NH3 synthesis in a plug-flow differential reactor was calculated using the following equation [27]: (38) r N H 3 = y N H 3 1 + y N H 3 × V 0 W c a t × 1 22.08 , where r N H 3 is the mass-averaged NH3 formation rates (mol gcat –1 h–1), y N H 3 is the mole fraction of NH3 at the outlet, V 0 is the total flow rate of the feed gas (L h–1, standard temperature and pressure (STP)), W c a t is the mass of the catalyst (gcat), and 22.08 is the molar volume of the feed gas (L mol–1, STP). All reported rates represent the steady-state values obtained following an initial break-in period (0.5–1 h) for each load of catalyst (Fig. S5). The NH3 yield ( Y N H 3 , %) is calculated using the following equation [27]: (39) Y N H 3 = F N H 3 , o u t l e t F N H 3 , t h e o r e t i c a l × 100 , where F N H 3 , o u t l e t is the molar flow rate of NH3 (molNH3 h–1) derived from r N H 3 , and F N H 3 , t h e o r e t i c a l is the theoretical molar flow rate (molNH3 h–1) at complete conversion. 4.4 DFT Calculations Periodic DFT calculations were performed using the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP) [47]. The generalized gradient approximation with the Perdew–Burke–Ernzerhof functional was employed to describe electron exchange and correlation [48]. A cut-off energy of 400 eV for plane wave expansion was used to represent valence electronic states. The projector augmented wave method was used to describe the interaction between valence and core electrons. A 1 × 1 × 1 Monkhorst-Pack mesh was used for k-point sampling. Electronic structures were optimized self-consistently until the energy variation was less than 10–5 eV, and all geometries were optimized until the residual force was less than 0.05 eV Å–1. The stoichiometric and reduced (Ov-formed) MoO2 surface was modeled based on the monoclinic MoO2 phase with the P21/C space group (a = 5.61 Å, b = 4.86 Å, c = 5.62 Å, β = 120.9°) [45]. The optimized bulk structure exhibited similar lattice parameters (a = 5.63 Å, 4.88 Å, 5.65 Å, β = 120.9°). The (011) surface was generated by (2 × 2) expansion of the optimized bulk structure. Three Mo layers were used, where the top MoO2 layer was relaxed and the bottom two MoO2 layers were fixed. Considering reductive treatment during the catalyst preparation, Ov-formed surfaces were also explored. Bridging O atoms on the surface were energetically favorable vacancy formation sites. The Ov formation energy (ΔEOv = (EOv/surface + 1/2 EO 2) – Esurface ) was 3.49 eV for the first Ov, and additional 3.83 eV of energy was required for the second Ov formation. Given that the metallic Mo was formed in the MoO3-N2/H2-600 sample (Fig. 2), a more reduced surface with two Ov was selected as a model surface for MoO3-N2/H2-600 (Fig. 7 (a)). The Mo2N structure with the tetragonal I41/amd space group (a = b = 4.2 Å, c = 8.0 Å) was used to model the Mo2N surface [46]. The optimized lattice parameters (a = b = 4.24 Å, c = 7.92 Å) were similar to those of the experimental results. The (001) surface was constructed by the expansion of (3 × 3) of the bulk structure with four Mo layers, where the bottom two layers were fixed. The structure of the Mo2N(001) surface resembled that of rock salt with alternating Nv, where half of the surface was covered by N atoms (i.e., θN = 0.5). To obtain more realistic surface structures, we examined the effects of N coverage on the surface energetics. For our surface unit cell, 9 Nv existed on the pristine surface, and up to 10 additional N atoms were added to the Nv. We assumed that NH3 is a source of N atoms (NH3 → N* + 1.5H2), and the N adsorption energy was calculated using the following equation: (40) Δ E x N a d s N H 3 = ( E x N M o 2 N ( 001 ) + 1.5 x E H 2 ) − ( E M o 2 N ( 001 ) + x E N H 3 ) where x denotes the number of adsorbed N atoms, ExN/Mo 2 N (001) denotes the total energy of the xN-adsorbed Mo2N surface, EMo 2 N (001) denotes the total energy of the pristine Mo2N(001) surface, and EH 2 and ENH 3 denote the total energies of the gaseous H2 and NH3 molecules, respectively. Using VASPKIT software, the relative free energies of the N-covered surfaces were then calculated based on the following equation: (41) Δ G x N a d s N H 3 = Δ E x N a d s N H 3 + Δ Z P E + Δ U 0 → T + T Δ S where ΔZPE is the zero-point energy correction, ΔU 0→ T is the thermal correction to the internal energy, and TΔS is the correction for the entropy contribution. To calculate ΔZPE and TΔS, vibrational frequencies of the adsorbed N atoms and H2 and NH3 molecules were calculated as described below. Similar calculations assuming N2 as a source of N atoms (0.5N2 → N*) were performed using the following equations: (42) Δ E x N a d s N 2 = E x N M o 2 N ( 001 ) − ( E M o 2 N ( 001 ) + 0.5 x E N 2 ) (43) Δ G x N a d s N 2 = Δ E x N a d s N 2 + Δ Z P E + Δ U 0 → T + T Δ S where EN 2 denotes the total energy of the gaseous N2 molecule. The free energy values were more negative than in the case of NH3 as the N source, but the trend of N coverage was considerably similar in both cases. Based on the results of relative free energies for N-covered Mo2N surfaces (Fig. S7(a) and S7(b)), the N-covered surfaces are energetically favorable, regardless of the N source. To compare the associative and dissociative mechanisms, reaction energetics were calculated on the N-covered surface with θN = 0.83 (Fig. S7(c)). Vibrational frequency calculations were performed to estimate the thermodynamic properties of the molecules and adsorbates. The frequencies were calculated from second-derivative matrices via the finite difference approach. The free energies were calculated via statistical mechanics formalism implemented in VASPKIT software [49]. Here, frequencies less than 50 cm–1 were set to 50 cm–1 to avoid significant inaccuracies in vibrational entropy partition functions. coredata.dc:description: The synthesis of NH3 from N2 and H2 is a significant chemical process, because essential products such as fertilizers and industrial chemicals can be obtained from NH3. In the catalytic synthesis of NH3, N2 activation is generally considered a kinetically relevant step (KRS). Therefore, advanced heterogeneous catalysts that promote N2 conversion have been extensively investigated. In this study, the roles of O and N vacancies (Ov and Nv) of Mo oxide formed during reduction were kinetically evaluated and compared using structural characterization, isotope experiments, kinetic studies, and density functional theory calculations. On the Mo oxide catalyst with Ov, NH3 was formed by a dissociative mechanism, and the surface reaction involving the adsorbed N* and H* was considered the KRS. However, on the catalyst with Nv, NH3 was formed by an associative mechanism, and N–N dissociation of N2H2* species by H* to produce NH3 was considered the KRS. The catalyst with Ov resulted in an NH3 synthesis rate of 5.6 mmol gMo −1 h−1 under relatively mild conditions (1.0 MPa and 400 °C), thus outperforming the catalyst with Nv (0.3 mmol gMo −1 h−1). These results provide insight into the importance of anionic vacancies in reducible metal oxides for NH3 synthesis.
